channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [ENTESB-5789] The creation of ssh container failed due to fabric8-karaf-1.2.0.redhat-621117.zip corrupted
item.description:
By creating a new SSH container with 6.2.1 R3 (621117), we got the following error due to the fabric8-karaf-1.2.0.redhat-621117.zip corrupted:

--- output ---
 
Running: mkdir -p /data/containers
 
Running: cd /data/containers
 
Running: mkdir -p ensemble_3
 
Running: cd ensemble_3
 
Java version is greater than 1.6.
 
Downloading Maven Artifact with groupId: io.fabric8 artifactId: fabric8-karaf and version: 1.2.0.redhat-621117 from repository: http://RH-PROD-01:8181/maven/download/
 
Using URL: http://RH-PROD-01:8181/maven/download/io/fabric8/fabric8-karaf/1.2.0.redhat-621117/fabric8-karaf-1.2.0.redhat-621117.zip
 
Running: extract_zip fabric8-karaf-1.2.0.redhat-621117.zip
 
Archive:  fabric8-karaf-1.2.0.redhat-621117.zip
 
  End-of-central-directory signature not found.  Either this file is not
 
  a zipfile, or it constitutes one disk of a multi-part archive.  In the
 
  latter case the central directory and zipfile comment will be found on
 
  the last disk(s) of this archive.
 
unzip:  cannot find zipfile directory in one of fabric8-karaf-1.2.0.redhat-621117.zip or
 
        fabric8-karaf-1.2.0.redhat-621117.zip.zip, and cannot find fabric8-karaf-1.2.0.redhat-621117.zip.ZIP, period.
 
Command Failed:Error running installation script: extract_zip fabric8-karaf-1.2.0.redhat-621117.zip
 
 
 
--- error ---
 
 
 
------
 
 
 
	at io.fabric8.service.ssh.SshContainerProvider.runScriptOnHost(SshContainerProvider.java:303)[275:io.fabric8.fabric-core-agent-ssh:1.2.0.redhat-621117]
 
	at io.fabric8.service.ssh.SshContainerProvider.create(SshContainerProvider.java:115)[275:io.fabric8.fabric-core-agent-ssh:1.2.0.redhat-621117]
 
	at io.fabric8.service.ssh.SshContainerProvider.create(SshContainerProvider.java:68)[275:io.fabric8.fabric-core-agent-ssh:1.2.0.redhat-621117]
 
	at io.fabric8.service.FabricServiceImpl$1.run(FabricServiceImpl.java:573)[142:io.fabric8.fabric-core:1.2.0.redhat-621117]
item.summary: The creation of ssh container failed due to fabric8-karaf-1.2.0.redhat-621117.zip corrupted

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Also, if SSH node can't fetch ZIP from server (root), which sees that no one is actually fetching/reading anything, maybe we should just wget/curl it from SSH node and check the operation using tcpdump? This looks completely like networking issue...

As in ENTESB-5717 there should be one change made to default profile:

profile-edit --pid 'io.fabric8.maven/io.fabric8.maven.defaultRepositories=${profile:io.fabric8.agent/org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.defaultRepositories}' default

with this change, when SSH container (or even it's creation bash script) asks fabric-maven-proxy for fabric8-karaf zip, root container won't look for this artifact externally, but rather serve it from its $FUSE_HOME/system.

Thanks Paolo,

Have never seen option --proxy-uri and had to double check that fabric:create --help does not document it either.
Isn't something like this done by default already? When testing I noticed I always had that file in /tmp after creating the SSH container.

This looks the same as ENTESB-5717. This:

Downloading Maven Artifact with groupId: io.fabric8 artifactId: fabric8-karaf and version: 1.2.0.redhat-621117 from repository: http://RH-PROD-01:8181/maven/download/

indicates that SSH container creation shell script tries to fetch fabric8-karaf distro from correct location. But as I said before:

  1. ssh container (or its creation script) tries to fetch arifact from fabric-maven-proxy
  2. fabric-maven-proxy relies on AetherBasedResolver configured using io.fabric8.maven PID and properties starting with io.fabric8.maven.
  3. there's no such property as io.fabric8.maven.defaultRepositories, so only io.fabric8.maven.repositories is used
  4. so even if fabric-maven-proxy (root container) has fabric8-karaf distro inside $FUSE_HOME/system it doesn't fetch it from there!

pretty please:

profile-edit --pid 'io.fabric8.maven/io.fabric8.maven.defaultRepositories=${profile:io.fabric8.agent/org.ops4j.pax.url.mvn.defaultRepositories}' default

I spent some time debugging every detail of Jetty 8's implementation of Async servlets. By the way, I've ensured myself that my change to how io.fabric8.maven.proxy.impl.MavenDownloadProxyServlet is implemented is correct WRT javax.servlet 3.0 specification.

But here's technical explanation of the problem.

Some information:

  • MavenDownloadProxyServlet sends requested artifacts in 64kB chunks using asynchronous servlet implementation
  • fabric8-karaf ZIP distro (fabric8-karaf-1.2.0.redhat-621121.zip) is exactly 86452318 bytes == 1319 chunks + 10334 bytes
  • our servlet reads 64kB chunks using java.nio.channels.AsynchronousFileChannel#read()
  • after reading the chunk, we have callback notification using thread from internal (NIO) thread pool
  • we call javax.servlet.AsyncContext#dispatch() to redispatch the request where we send 64kB to servlet output stream and read next 64kB using two flip buffers

Jetty assumes that progress is in 3 situations:

  • requests headers are just parsed
  • there's output in http generator, but it's not ASYNC request (see here)
  • there's other progress related for example to SSL (not relevant here)

second condition changes ONLY after javax.servlet.AsyncContext#dispatch() is called - after sending entire fabric8-karaf distro.

And now the race condition. ASYNC servlet handling in Jetty 8 is a series of dispatches. Async servlets are usually implemented as series of "do something + javax.servlet.AsyncContext#dispatch()", so server threads are spared and traffic may be much higher.
Each AsyncContext#dispatch() reschedules underlying org.eclipse.jetty.io.nio.SelectChannelEndPoint's handler to run again. If AsyncContext#dispatch() is quicker, than we loop inside org.eclipse.jetty.server.AbstractHttpConnection#handleRequest(). Otherwise, we quit this loop and do progress checking.
Each time AsyncContext#dispatch() is delayed (slow IO?), org.eclipse.jetty.server.AsyncHttpConnection#_total_no_progress is increased and if it goes beyond (by default) 100, we have:

INFO  | qtp424809312-202 | AsyncHttpConnection              | 86 - org.eclipse.jetty.aggregate.jetty-all-server - 8.1.19.v20160209 | EndPoint making no progress: 100

if it reaches 200, we have:

WARN  | qtp424809312-206 | AsyncHttpConnection              | 86 - org.eclipse.jetty.aggregate.jetty-all-server - 8.1.19.v20160209 | Closing EndPoint making no progress: 200

and socket is forcibly closed even if MavenDownloadProxyServlet didn't finish it's work.

So the race condition is with these two threads fighting for synchronized block:
Jetty 8:

"qtp1328601240-280@10932" prio=5 tid=0x118 nid=NA runnable
 
  java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
 
	  at org.eclipse.jetty.server.AsyncContinuation.unhandle(AsyncContinuation.java:405)
 
	  at org.eclipse.jetty.server.AbstractHttpConnection.handleRequest(AbstractHttpConnection.java:565)
 
	  at org.eclipse.jetty.server.AsyncHttpConnection.handle(AsyncHttpConnection.java:79)
 
	  at org.eclipse.jetty.io.nio.SelectChannelEndPoint.handle(SelectChannelEndPoint.java:696)
 
	  at org.eclipse.jetty.io.nio.SelectChannelEndPoint$1.run(SelectChannelEndPoint.java:53)
 
	  at org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.QueuedThreadPool.runJob(QueuedThreadPool.java:608)
 
	  at org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.QueuedThreadPool$3.run(QueuedThreadPool.java:543)
 
	  at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)

and NIO thread that calls java.nio.channels.CompletionHandler#completed():

"Thread-127@10946" daemon prio=5 tid=0x11a nid=NA runnable
 
  java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
 
	  at org.eclipse.jetty.server.AsyncContinuation.dispatch(AsyncContinuation.java:452)
 
	  at io.fabric8.maven.proxy.impl.MavenDownloadProxyServlet$2.completed(MavenDownloadProxyServlet.java:166)
 
	  at io.fabric8.maven.proxy.impl.MavenDownloadProxyServlet$2.completed(MavenDownloadProxyServlet.java:161)
 
	  at sun.nio.ch.Invoker.invokeUnchecked(Invoker.java:126)
 
	  at sun.nio.ch.SimpleAsynchronousFileChannelImpl$2.run(SimpleAsynchronousFileChannelImpl.java:335)
 
	  at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142)
 
	  at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)
 
	  at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)

And that's all... Workaround in next comment, so we can make it public

Because Jetty 9 has totally reimplemented ASYNC handlers code, we can simply DISABLE this weird progress checking. Please set these two system properties (bin/setenv or etc/system.properties):

org.mortbay.jetty.NO_PROGRESS_INFO=0
 
org.mortbay.jetty.NO_PROGRESS_CLOSE=0
It works without any problems in Jetty 9.
